What I Use 2025

Sep 24, 2025

I’ve been exploring various What I Use posts coming across the feed, and I found this site that started the prompt and collects a lot of the entries at their site. I haven’t listened to the podcast that kicked it off (also at the link), but I like the idea and want to start cataloging that my list too.

There was a brief moment where I learned about new tools everyday, and tried to catalog them here. But this table is where I am at in late 2025. Many entries in the below table make me think “this deserves a full write-up”, while others make me think “I am starting to hate this, I wonder if there are alternatives. A worthwhile exercise to revisit next year. Gift links are marked with an emoji.

Category App
📨 Mail Client Shortwave
📮 Mail Server Gmail
📝 Notes Obsidian
📓 Journal Day One
✅ To-Do Todoist
📷 iPhone Photo Shooting Not my circus, not my monkeys
🟦 Photo Storage Synology Photos
📆 Calendar Samsung Calendar
📁 Cloud File Storage Synology Drive
📖 RSS Newsblur, Readwise Reader 🎁
🙍🏻‍♂️ Contacts Samsung contacts
🌐 Browser Arc on Windows/Android, Zen Browser on Linux
💬 Chat Beeper client, but mostly Telegram
🔖 Bookmarks Raindrop
📑 Read It Later Readwise Reader 🎁
📜 Word Processing, 📈 Spreadsheets, 📊 Presentations Whatever the client is using
🛒 Shopping Lists Field Notes
🍴 Meal Planning winging it lol but using Paprika for recipes
💰 Budgeting and Personal Finance YNAB
📰 News Bluesky for breaking, Defector and The Verge for analysis
🎵 Music Symfonium with Plex backend
🎤 Podcasts Pocket Casts 🎁
🔐 Password Management 1Password

Hipster tendencies in sports fandom

Aug 20, 2025

Every fan has their idiosyncrasies, especially sports fans. We are all unique little flowers, some vibrant and full of joy, some woeful yet resilient. Every one has their little habit and routine (even the players), which makes me certain I am not the only jersey hipster.

What is a jersey hipster, you ask? Well, when you get a sports jersey, there is generally a player’s name and number on it.1 A fairweather fan can pick the most popular jersey; there will be a lot of them in the team shop after all. But true sickos understand the future value of remembering some guys, and look for a contrarian jersey pick, down the depth chart. This is the jersey hipster.

I’ll use my “woeful” teams from the link above as an example. Would I enjoy a Caitlin Clark 22 Fever jersey? Maybe2, but I’d appreciate a Natasha Howard jersey more. Tyrese Haliburton deserves all the attention, but I’m sticking with my Bogdanavic. Didn’t the Colts have two generational talents at the most important position in football in the last couple decades? Yes they did.3 Surely I picked up one of those shirts? Absolutely not—I represent undersung linebacker Shaq Leonard (neé Darius) on game day.

Maybe it follows with age and maturity, but I remember music hipsters being far more exclusionary than someone in a Darren McCarty #25 sweater. I’m not going to read much more into it than that, though. I’ll probably just remember another guy. Lance Stephenson.

  1. Hockey “jerseys” are outerwear, and baseball “jerseys” are a subtype of a Hawaiian shirt, so the name/number rules may or may not apply, YMMV. ↩︎

  2. I’ve come around on the Stranger Things colorway - it is actually good ↩︎

  3. How about the last 5-6 seasons? Mind your business. ↩︎

Aug 13, 2025

lol. lmao even

🔗: ESPN: Sports Misery Index

Aug 13, 2025

🔗: Desperately Seeking Software

Paul Ford reviews ChatGPT 5 and finds it lacking.

I just wish to God one person in LLMworld could work on a bad Salesforce deploy, or maintain and enhance a plugin-laden but business-critical WordPress install. I want them to see the gap between the software world most people experience—including most developers—and the infinitely funded world of pine floors and plant walls where they thrive.

Aug 12, 2025

let’s test out the wifi at this Fever-Wings game 🏀

The robots

Aug 11, 2025

Alright, after some travel and some work obligations, time to finally sit down and write something for Blaugust. The topic du jour is AI, and I don’t think I have laid out where I am aligned.

Large language models and generative AI seem useful, in the conceptual phase. Summarizing jargon-filled documents, touching up photos, maybe generating code in a language you aren’t familiar with yet - sounds practical and dare I say helpful!

The problem, as with almost all current tech problems, is scale. Rather than create a useful product/service tailored to users’ wants and needs, the tech industry chases growth at all costs. That means expanding “touch up a photo” to generating deep fakes, and accepting that any summarized document is probably getting vacuumed into the hive mind training the next version of the LLM.

I personally do not have a lot of experience using LLMs. I am a state contractor, and we are expressly prohibited from using them for work (for now). But my limited experience has been underwhelming, like the time I tried to generate a fake email address. It feels like these computer tools are great at communicating, but much worse at tasks a computer used to do well.

This communication “skill” leads to one of the biggest traps with LLMs: the attribution of thought behind that communication (succinctly summarized by Rusty Foster here). There is no thought to this computer communication, just pattern matching using the entire corpus of human writing. But it seems to fool even the people creating and selling it.

Will Leitch outlines a view of AI that matches my own: there are valid uses for it, but most of the hype is geared toward the benefit of cheap, intellectually lazy people. And if you generate something with AI and pass it off as your own, you have missed the assignment completely:

This is the thing: Writing is meaning. The reason we write things is to express some sort of meaning, to pass along important information, to convey a human emotion or sensation. It doesn’t matter whether the writing is grammatically correct, or vividly expressed. It matters that it came from you. That is the point of writing. If you ask a Chatbot to write something for you, you are being fundamentally unhuman and foundationally dishonest. ... If it requires an AI bot for you to express something to me, you and I are probably not actually friends. Will Leitch

I started this blog post a week ago. Could it have been written faster with ChatGPT? Maybe. But it would not have been written by me, and that is the point.

adding to The Bluesky Dictionary by acting “millennially” today - preparing for global economic recession, eating avocado toast, etc

Blaugust 2025

Aug 2, 2025

While I don’t consider myself a content creator, I am in the right headspace to pick up a mini challenge to create some blog posts with regularity. Blaugust 2025 sounds like fun. I’ll probably adhere to the optional calendar and prompts here, because one of the biggest writing impediments (in my experience) is just finding a topic.

I found out about Blaugust through my Micro.blog feed - specifically @birming and @heyloura. I did not plan ahead at all because I learned about it on August 2! Hopefully I can get to 15 posts with at least a few sentences in them, but will probably boost my output with link blogging and photos. Watch this space!

Pieces of writing for Blaugust:

  • The robots
  • Hipster tendencies in sports fandom

Jul 26, 2025

Jul 25, 2025

Rusty Foster with the cleanest distillation of LLM confusion I’ve seen, in Today In Tabs:

The essential problem is this: generative language software is very good at producing long and contextually informed strings of language, and humanity has never before experienced coherent language without any cognition driving it. In regular life, we have never been required to distinguish between “language” and “thought” because only thought was capable of producing language, in any but the most trivial sense.

Lord Huron July 18

Jul 18, 2025

After seeing Lord Huron at Red Rocks in May, wouldn’t you know it, they kicked off their tour to support their new album in our city. Couldn’t pass it up.

It’s our third Lord Huron show (Indy 2022, with the kiddo), but the first one we got to hear Ends Of The Earth. The new stuff sounds fun (Cosmic Selector - out now!), but I really enjoyed the sped up versions of La Belle Fleur Sauvage and Frozen Pines. And maybe I just don’t go to many shows, but the production design on these Lord Huron shows is incredible. The pay phone, the tube TVs, the dancers, everything. The play between the lights and the LED screen was impressive. This was how the encore started:

Hadn’t been to this amphitheatre before, and it’s really nice. Also pretty sure I had never been to a show where someone had to be taken to what the Hold Steady called “the chill out tent”, but at least 2 people near us did not make it past the opener (Indigo de Souza - need to look her back catalog up, she was great).

Jul 9, 2025

🔗: The Galaxy Z Fold 7 is super slim, but say goodbye to the S Pen | The Verge

Pouring one out for the S-Pen, one of my favorite stupid Android things

State of Android 2025

Jul 7, 2025

Besides roughly 2 months in 2015, I have been an Android guy1 almost since Android was a thing. My first smartphone was a Motorola Droid 22, and I’ve run through LG and HTC and Google phones before my current streak of Samsung Galaxies Note/Ultra. I have been around this particular block a few times. And while I don’t follow the developments as closely as I once did, I want to take stock of where Android is in 2025.

Market movements

I got started with Android for likely the same reason many (millennial and older) US-based customers did: AT&T had an exclusive deal with the iPhone, and I was on Verizon. In my brief jaunt with an iPhone 6S Plus as my daily driver, I could not stomach being defaulted into Apple’s messaging app, and email, and browser, etc. I am a tinkerer, and I need things to tweak and change and try to keep me engaged. There were too many launchers and clients and power-user utilities to sample on the other side of the fence.

There was also a plethora of hardware tweaks and differentiations between manufacturers. LG would put the fingerprint reader on the back of the phone. HTC added a second camera and started the bokeh trend. Motorola went above in beyond in letting you customize your phone. Samsung would throw in every feature under the sun to see what sticks.

That is generally no longer the case. Part of that is maturity of the platform, but another big part is consolidation. Of the companies listed above, LG doesn’t make phones anymore. Google absorbed Motorola, then un-absorbed it so they could absorb HTC. Samsung is still here, and so the US market is really just Google and Samsung, with one more not yet mentioned.

Plus one

OnePlus is one of the fun wildcards keeping the Android ecosystem honest. It is the formula they have since they started - do the essentials as well or better than the competition, pare down some non-essentials for BOM cost, and come in at a price point 20-40% below comparable devices.

(Here I want to clarify that I am focusing on the US market, and specifically mainstream smartphones. I know that OnePlus is essentially the US subsidiary of Oppo, and that Oppo and Xiaomi and Huawei and others are all doing awesome hardware that we will never get to see stateside. I also know Boox and Fairphone and the Light Phone and many other unique hardware applications underpinned by an Android operating system. All great, worthy of a separate post, but not the subject of this one.)

I have always wanted OnePlus to succeed, but my one foray into OnePlus phones ended in a police report because it never got delivered. Instead I re-upped as a proud Galaxy Note user.

Notes on notes

In that post linked at the top, I note the differentiator of the Note:

The S-pen would probably increase smartphone adoption among the older demographic if it were packaged with more phones. There is something satisfying about pulling it out and launching the built-in note app and jotting things down. It is still not faster than typing; the last several years have conditioned me to type faster than I write. But I am still conditioned to remember things that I write down with a pen or pencil.

It is still extremely satisfying in 2025! In the intervening years, Samsung added a tiny battery in the S-pen, and you can use it as a remote for things like the camera shutter. No one else does this! This is the stuff that makes me love technology. Which is why it sucks that the only difference between Samsung’s flagship 2025 and 2024 phones, as far as I can tell, is removing this specific feature and adding “AI” to the names of existing features.

Foldable horizon

The only real ray of light, signaling any sort of ambition toward the future of mobile, is the foldable. These devices represent the only tangible innovation in the space, among a sea of 5.5 inch metal and glass candy bars. If you have not tried one, I’m going to use the same description from the S-pen: it is extremely satisfying to mechanically shut your phone. It is fun to have a tablet that changes to fit in your pocket, or even a clamshell that fits even deeper in your pocket. True millennials know the power of slamming your phone shut at the end of a call, and it is high time to reintroduce that to smartphones. I got to use one of these (Samsung Z Fold 3) for roughly a year, and would definitely go back.3

These should be the cutting edge of mobile computing. In reality though, Samsung has finely tuned 6 separate iterations of their foldables, to the point that it seems impossible to change it either positively or negatively. Google jumped in with their own unique contender that seems to get less unique each year. Even OnePlus put out a great foldable… once. It is now 2 years old4 and doesn’t have a successor.

What Next?

This blog was created for two purposes. First: in migrating and reading through old posts, I realized I had not put anything like this together in almost a decade. So, stretching my legs (fingers). Second, even more self-serving purpose: I am working through my thoughts on my next phone upgrade. I am currently using a Galaxy S23 Ultra (for the uninitiated, this is the “pro” model with every feature under the sun, including the stylus). But it is two years old, which is roughly when I have upgraded.5

But looking around, there really is nothing that improves upon what I already have. Samsung is announcing their 7th foldable in a few days, but the battery is the same size as the model I tried from 4 years ago (10% smaller than my current phone). Pixels have always had good reviews, but I am more wary than ever about investing my digital life in Google.

The current differentiators are: how locked into the platform are you? (Very.) How much do you trust the platform operator? (🤏.) Do you want to spend the equivalent of a budget laptop or a high-end laptop? (No comment.) Do “AI” features matter to you in the least? (Absolutely not.) To bring it back to the title, the Android market in 2025 is pretty dire.

  1. I casually mention late in this post that I was dual-booting between Samsung and AOSP ROMs, an incredibly cool and stupid thing to do with any daily driver device that I had completely forgotten I did. To be young and dumb… ↩︎

  2. Missed the OG Droid by a few months, which remains the greatest form factor for a mobile device. ↩︎

  3. I swapped it due to an issue with the outer screen (the less difficult one to repair!), that I could not get repaired because of Samsung changing warranty providers and messing up some serial numbers on the back end… will maybe go over this another time when it doesn’t still sting lol ↩︎

  4. Anymore, this is “mid-life crisis” age for consumer technology. ↩︎

  5. Acknowledging here that this is extremely privileged! A big feature from both Android and Apple in the past few years is upping the software maintenance window to 5-7 years. Many devices linked in the first section of this blog would not even be able to connect to a network anymore. ↩︎

🔗: YunoHost

YunoHost is a system that installs itself on a serverand allows you to install and maintain - with very little technical knowledge - digital services (apps) that you control.

this could fix me

Jun 23, 2025

🔗: The Pacers Were Too Cool To Make Sense | Defector

The experience of watching the Pacers throughout this postseason run was the experience of watching such a protracted sequence of irrational things happen, to the point that they made sense. You are not supposed to steal inbounds passes, run off of every made layup, or suddenly turn into a deadeye stepback shooter. … Aaron Nesmith is not supposed to turn into Ray Allen for like two minutes and make six threes. Tyrese Haliburton is not supposed to make every potential game-winner. T.J. McConnell is not supposed to turn into Michael Jordan for five minutes of a Game 7. All-star opponents are not supposed to forget how to dribble the basketball late in games.

A Pacer Appreciation

Jun 23, 2025

The Indiana Pacers fell in game 7 of the NBA Finals last night. Tyrese Haliburton’s leg exploding in slow motion proved to be a tragic end to an incredible season, and it deserves an appreciation.

This is a team that lost 70% of their games 3 seasons ago. Management turned over the roster and handed the keys to Tyrese Haliburton and built an offensive juggernaut out of mostly standard-issue guys. Last year they outperformed expectations by winning 2 playoff rounds, and most pundits wrote it off as a fluke.

I was at best a casual fan, given my only team jersey was picked up on clearance after a Fever game because that guy left in free agency. But after last season, I shelled out for the local TV broadcasts (FanDuel Sports Network neé Bally Sports neé Fox Sports Midwest) so I could actually watch the games. And it did not disappoint. When everyone was healthy (after mid-December or so), this Pacers team was never fully out of a game.

In this year’s playoffs, the Pacers kept up the trend. They kept running into teams with superstars and strong cores, and they kept throwing them in the trash can in increasingly unlikely ways.

It truly was a miraculous run, given that most metrics showed they should not have made it this far:

The Pacers have a chance to become the worst team to ever win the NBA Finals (seriously it's a compliment to their playoff run; I love Indianapolis; it's my favorite Midwestern city outside of Chicago in May). Subscribe to The Pulse (it's free) & get me on weekends www.nytimes.com/athletic/new...

[image or embed]

— Alex Kirshner ([@alexkirshner.com](http://alexkirshner.com)) June 22, 2025 at 7:24 PM

They became the first team to have 8 different players score 200+ points in a single playoff. It shows that talent-wise, having several high floors can compete with one or two high ceilings. The worst part of it all (besides the hideous injury) is that the element of surprise is gone. If they do it again, the story will just be “there go those rascally Pacers again, punching above their weight”. Regardless, this is the kind of season that creates lifelong fans.

Jun 19, 2025

Tiny Theme customizations for this site

Jun 19, 2025

I have had plenty of time to tinker since migrating to micro.blog, and something I always forgot to do on Wordpress was document tweaks and settings and plugins as I implemented them. I’m going to try to make up for that here.

I’ve bounced between a few different themes, but I keep coming back to Tiny by Matt Langford. Micro.blog has much better documentation around customizations - see custom.micro.blog. But Matt’s themes (he also make Sumo and Bayou) carve out places to insert your own customizations throughout, called microhooks. Here are my customizations.

Home page

On the homepage, I updated the navigation bar to add a link to the old Wordpress blog. This is done by adding the following in the microhook-inline-nav-end.html:

<li><a class="old-site" href="https://wp.pilch.me">the old blog</a></li>

I also updated the pagination to add page numbers. This was accomplished with the microhook-pagination.html file. This microhook replaces the default pagination, so I copied the entire <div> containing that html into the microhook file, and added my page numbers in between the ‘older’ and ’newer’ links. I found I also had to redeclare the $paginator in this file in order for this to work:

{{ $paginator := .Paginate (where .Site.Pages.ByDate.Reverse "Type" "post") }}
<div class="post-nav">
  {{ if $paginator.HasPrev }}
  <span class="prev">
    <a href="{{ $paginator.Prev.URL }}" title="Previous Page"><span class="arrow">← Newer</span></a>
  </span>
  {{ end }}
  <span class=“page-number”>
	Page {{ $pag.PageNumber }} of {{ $pag.TotalPages }}
	</span>
  {{ if $paginator.HasNext }}
  <span class="next">
    <a href="{{ $paginator.Next.URL }}"><span class="arrow">Older →</span></a>
  </span>
  {{ end }}
</div>

Posts

I like cross-posting, and used it a lot on the old blog. I currently only cross-post to Bluesky and Mastodon, so I wanted to show links to those next to the post sent to those sites. This was pretty simple for Bluesky, but I had some issues with the Mastodon URL and had to build it with printf from other attributes.

The free fonts and icons from FontAwesome are included in Tiny Theme, so I used those for the syndication icons. All together it looks like this:

{{ if or (.Params.bluesky) (.Params.mastodon) }}
<p>
    Also on: 
{{ if .Params.bluesky }}
<a class="u-syndication" {{ printf "href=%q" .Params.bluesky.link | safeHTMLAttr }}><i class="fa-brands fa-bluesky"></i></a>
{{ end }}
{{ if .Params.mastodon }}
{{ $mastolink := printf "%d" .Params.mastodon.id  | printf "@%s/%s" .Params.mastodon.username | printf "%s/%s" .Params.mastodon.hostname  | printf "https://%s" }}
<a class="u-syndication" {{ printf "href=%q" $mastolink | safeHTMLAttr }}><i class="fa-brands fa-mastodon"></i></a>
{{ end }}
</p>
  {{ end }}

I also really liked Loura’s implementation of backlinks, so I rolled that into the same file. Adding both of these snippets to microhook-after-post.html displays them in the correct place.

Archive

I prefer the way that Sumo Theme’s archive buttons look, better than the default bullet list in Tiny Theme. So I changed the <ul> to the following <div> in layouts/_default/list.archivehtml.html :

<div class="archive-categories">
		<h3>{{ T "Categories" }}</h3>
		<div class="category-list">
			{{ range $list }}
			<a href="{{ .Permalink }}"><button>{{ .Title }}</button></a>
			{{ end }}
		</div>
	</div>

Indieweb

I’ve long been an indieweb nerd, and part of the reason for migrating here was having much of that functionality out of the box. However, some of the baseline tags were missing - specifically the h-card. I tweaked the header.html file until I could validate the h-card on indiewebify.me.

Basically, I just had to wrap my avatar, site link, and description with <span class="h-card">. When I remember, I might even put this in as a pull request on these theme repositories. I know there are rel=me links elsewhere in the header, which may or may not belong in the h-card, but that is for future tweaking. For now my up-to-date rel=me links are on my about page.

Jun 6, 2025
Haliburton has now made four game-winning or game-tying buckets in the final five seconds of a game during this postseason. That shot also gave the Pacers their fifth 15-point comeback victory in this postseason, and we are now at the point where a generation's worth of miraculous shots and outcomes have been produced by one team over the course of two months. Haliburton's shot from last night deserves to be the first thing that anyone thinks about when the 2025 Pacers are mentioned in the future, but it will have to get in line behind eight Points In 47 Seconds and Down 14 With 2:51 Left To Play.
Tom Ley https://defector.com/we-must-consider-whether-the-pacers-have-a-pact-with-beelzebub-himself

Colorado road trip, 2025

Jun 5, 2025

It had been a couple years since the last family road trip, and several more years since the last family reunion. So we helped plan a large get together with my extended family near where many of them live in Colorado.

We took the opportunity to turn it into a whole week of sight seeing. Took in a Lord Huron show at Red Rocks, checked out the Denver Zoo, and of course drove up Trail Ridge Road in Rocky Mountain National Park.

We got back Sunday but my brain is still on mountain time. While I recover, enjoy these photos of nature.

Pacers headed back to the conference finals

May 14, 2025

Got a Ray Ratto write-up at Defector for the occasion: 🔗 No One Ever Sees The Pacers Coming

Yet there is something to this Pacers team that a certain stripe of basketball psycho has recognized, which is that they produce offense with a level of ease that few teams have, and defend with a quirky stubbornness that casuals catch onto only after the games end. They lead the league in nothing but are better than average at everything, all of which was on clear display Tuesday when they closed out the Cleveland Cavaliers, 114-105.

Ratto hits on what I have been struggling to explain to friends: the Pacers don’t have the guy. The one guy you could argue as their guy got voted the most overrated guy by all the other guys in the league (sidenote: seems fairly accurately rated now). Haliburton has had his share of great stat lines and clutch shots, but Myles Turner put the nail in the Cavs yesterday. Andrew Nembhard had one against the Bucks in round 1, and last year against the Knicks, this year’s presumptive ECF opponent.

By not having the guy where everything goes through that guy, you (the opponent, and also the viewer) never know where the Pacers are going to get you. Conventional basketball wisdom was that you need the guy. But we’ve got 2 seasons of evidence that maybe you don’t need 1 crazy-high ceiling, just a lot of very-high floors.

It's about jobs in video game journalism

May 1, 2025

Polygon getting sold (and gutted) is a huge bummer. To a chumbox company with “sweat shop” conditions, no less. I found so many games through their site. My most recent finished playthroughs, Thank Goodness You’re Here and The Case of the Golden Idol were recommendations from them. It had great writing and was a resource to build a well-rounded backlog and learn about the gaming industry, without a bunch of culture war bullshit.

It’s a characteristically far-sighted move by Vox management to liquidate their gaming vertical right before the Switch 2 release, and GTA 6 later this year. Those guys could not sell sunscreen at a beach.

Polygon was one of two gaming sites in my RSS reader. The other is Aftermath. I really hope someplace like Aftermath can pick up some of these writers. Need more worker-owned publications in this media landscape.

🔗: Bucks Collapse Leads To Giannis Antetokounmpo Delivering Fatherhood Lessons To Tyrese Haliburton’s Dad

One camera angle from inside the arena shows Antetokounmpo staring in disbelief, possibly running through all the reputational and financial consequences that would come with punching this older, normal-sized man in the throat.

This was a wild finish. Benedict Mathurin also got into it with Giannis after the game, for what I assume were separate, dumb reasons. But it made me so happy when the ball popped through Gary Trent Jr.’s legs, after he had cooked the Pacers in OT. Giannis and Dame are so cool, it’s too bad the rest of their team sucks

A Boilermaker Appreciation

Mar 20, 2025

If you ever read this blog or my socials, there is a good chance the post you read is about the Purdue Boilermakers. While I (sometimes) enjoy the football team’s exploits, my true passion is the men’s basketball team. We are based in Indiana, after all. To folks who are unfamiliar with the joys & plights Boilermaker basketball, here is the lowdown.

School History

Why is the mascot of Purdue a “boilermaker”? It goes back to a football game in the late 1800s. The Purdue football team travelled to nearby Wabash College for a game, and trounced them. Reporters for the local newspaper seized on the size difference between the teams’ players, and called them names, heavily implying that Purdue was employing local rail workers. “Pumpkin-shuckers”, “coal heavers”, “blacksmiths”, “stevedores”, and the one that stuck - boilermakers.

To this day, the official mascot is the Boilermaker Special, a road-legal vehicle built to look like a steam engine. It is the fastest official mascot in college athletics, reaching speeds of 75 mph on the highway.

Team History

The Purdue men’s basketball team is a winner. Just not when you get to the post season.1

Purdue won it’s last national championship in 1932, before the advent of the NCAA tournament, behind the guard play of John Wooden. You may remember him from winning 10 titles as the coach of UCLA. Well, where did he learn the game?

The school has the most conference titles in the Big Ten, and has 36 tournament appearances to its name. But it only has 3 Final Fours and no championships to show for it. When I started following (see next section), it was a combination of horrifically-timed injuries, jitters/choking (this one got its own Wikipedia page), and just plain bad luck.2

The obvious comparison for non-CBB fans was to the Chicago Cubs, with their famous curse and geographic proximity to northern Indiana. But they finally broke theirs. I would consider the Minnesota Vikings as a better comparison now, with the most all-times wins without a Super Bowl to show for it. Never an underdog, but never the last one standing either.

“But wait!” you say. “Didn’t they make the Final Four last year?” Yes, a year removed from losing so bad it got it’s own Wikipedia page, roughly the same roster stormed through the tournament and made their first Final Four since 1980. We got to play in the natty the same day as the Great North American Eclipse passed through. As a fan, I would guess we will be back when the next eclipse rolls through in 20 years or so.

tfw your team is playing in the championship tonight #BoilerUp #marchmadness

[image or embed]

— craig ([@craig.pilch.me](http://craig.pilch.me)) April 8, 2024 at 7:11 PM

Player appreciation

Of course there are the recent All-Americans and draft picks. Zach Edey was the first back-to-back consensus national player of the year in 4 decades. Carsen Edwards had no shooting conscience, and was allowed to go supernova, breaking Steph Curry’s tournament shooting records. Robbie Hummel, E’Twaun Moore and Jajuan Johnson catapulted Matt Painter’s recruiting, dubbed the Baby Boilers. And Hummel is now an outstanding color commentator for national CBB broadcasts.

And part of the reason I started this blog was to publish my bonafides on current Big Ten player of the year and All-American point guard Braden Smith.

True fans, though, have a soft spot for the guys who are not at the top of the scouting report. Shout outs to Gordon Watt, Chris Lutz, Keaton Grant, Chris Kramer, Marcus Green and Bobby Riddell, from my formative fan years. My Purdue jersey, although Camden Heide and Jaden Ivey are the most recent wearers of the number, is a Lewis Jackson jersey.

My History

My freshman year coincided with a changing of the guard in the men’s basketball team. Gene Keady had just retired, at the time the second-winningest coach in Big Ten history. His protege was a former player who had just seen some success as the head coach at Southern Illinois.

My friends and I had season tickets, and joined the student section, which needed to be renamed. It was previously “The Gene Pool”, and so to hold the theme it was now called “The Paint Crew”, in honor of new coach Matt Painter.

Coach Painter went 9-19 in that first year at Purdue. That did not matter – it was a magical experience. Again, shout out to Gary Ware, Chris Lutz, Marcus Green and Bobby Riddell. I’ve never yelled as loud as I did when we knocked off Michigan that year. Even in a down year, Mackey Arena is a special place. We were hooked for life.

The next year, Painter took Carl Landry and David Teague back to the NCAA tournament, and despite maybe 1-2 exceptions, has fielded a team competing for conference (and sometimes national) titles basically every year since. He has the 4th-most wins in Big Ten History, behind 3 guys who coached 5-10 years longer than he has, and will likely pass his mentor in the next couple years.

I have not been back since pre-Covid, but when I see it on TV I can feel Mackey Arena in my bones. It is the loudest venue I have ever been, referred to as ‘a concrete dungeon of sound’ regularly reaching 120db jet-engine levels during conference play. I get hearing loss just remembering games there.

The Future

It feels bright! Even though Purdue is tipping off against High Point as I publish this (As I fan I hear High Point and it rhymes with VCU and Little Rock and North Texas). I know Coach Painter is not going to get several future NBA stars onto a team together. He is going to find unsung recruits and turn them into school legends. Maybe not March legends, but January legends at the very least.

  1. Of course I am only referring to the men’s team here. Purdue women’s basketball won a natty in 1999. ↩︎

  2. I will never post a video of this game, but the bad luck part is pretty obvious if you watch the final seconds of regulation. I will never forget the look Carsen Edwards gives the UVA player who hit the buzzer beater, as OT starts. It’s like, “really?” ↩︎

Mar 18, 2025

RETVRN

Why are we making new Pebble-like smartwatches?

Pretty simple - because we want one! No company has made a perfect smartwatch for people like us, so we’re going to make the exact smartwatch we want.

https://ericmigi.com/blog/introducing-two-new-pebbleos-watches

Catch up post for 2025

Mar 17, 2025

Reviewing old posts is dredging up a lot of memories, and I realize I should probably document some empty areas in the timeline of this site.1

2021

Most of 2021 was spent trying to restore a rhythm that had been lost during the pandemic. Getting a kid back in school, changing work clients, traveling to see people that we couldn’t the prior year. It takes a lot of focus away from little things, like blogging.

2022

I endear myself to my new-ish employer enough to take on a major project, which goes to production during this year. Taught myself how to do API testing.

Oh, and we adopted Willow, our Irish wolfhound - poodle mix. She started so small, and is now 80 pounds.

My social media habits migrated from Twitter to Mastodon, as shadow president ruined the former.

2023

No big deal, just had another kid lol. Grey was born 4 weeks early, but is all caught up and toddlering around.

I snagged an invite to Bluesky around July, and tried to rebuild my posting muscles there. But it always felt like something was missing (it was my blog).

2024

My 2024 started with a car accident lol. Everybody was fine (on our end), but we were hit and run while going through a green light at an intersection. If you can afford a Volvo, I apparently endorse them with my life.

The rest of 2024 was picking up another large API project at work, and remembering how much work a toddler is lol.

2025 so far

Something prompted an urge to return to the blogs. Maybe the state of the world made me want to give me something that I could control. But the state of my Wordpress backend necessitated a move to Micro.blog. So that is where I am at - back to blogging.

  1. That is 13 years old and counting ↩︎

Micro.blog import status

Feb 12, 2025

Part of the impetus for importing my Wordpress into micro.blog is the amount of errors caused by trying and forgetting various plug-ins over the years.

This screen is from bulk updating posts (to add an export tag, so I can move things in smaller pieces). Hitting back in the browser shows that the bulk update succeeded, but it does this every time. If I had more time, I might be able to sit down and figure this out. But right now, forward progress is getting all the relevant content to the new host.

So far I’m back to imported FB posts from over 10 years ago. After that, it will be deciding what to do with link posts, which will require some reformatting. But progress is progress.

Jan 24, 2025

🔗 Samsung’s S25 and S25 Plus offer more of the same

Other AI abilities are just as familiar, but we didn’t always call them AI. Take AI Select, accessed from Samsung’s Edge Panel, which gives “suggested actions” like cropping and sharing screenshots, creating GIFs from videos, or adding events to your calendar. It replaces Smart Select, which did most of that, too, but with a different design.

🔥🔥🔥

The S25 phones also offer a daily summary called Now Brief that lets you know what’s on your calendar for the day or how your commute looks, bringing us back full circle to 2012’s Google Now. Meanwhile, the Now Bar is Samsung’s answer to Apple’s Dynamic Island: a lockscreen element that can show sports scores and Google Maps navigation instructions or tell you what song is playing. It sounds useful, but is it AI? Apple didn’t think so.

May 5, 2022

been trying to come up with words, and as usual the people paid to come up with words professionally say it much better

🔗: The Difference Between Protest and Resistance | Kelsey McKinney and Laura Wagner (Defector)

May 1, 2022

a great day to start a plumbing project on a whim (it is never a great day to start a plumbing project, especially on a whim)

🔗: Damian Lillard Is A Waking Nightmare | Defector

When Lillard fully enters Dame Time—which does not involve him cynically baiting defenders into fouls on the perimeter, or meticulously crafting open looks through the offense, or wildly attacking the rim and hoping for the best—there is no meaner sight in sports. There's just a guy, pulling up from 25–35 feet over and over and over again, making shots that nobody can do a single thing to stop.

The GameStop chaos is what happens when a stock becomes a meme. While the Redditors of r/WallStreetBets are buying options, GameStop shorts are getting squeezed, and some big Wall Street firms are making profits. Here’s what happens when retail investment starts getting social.

Stupid coup reading catch-up

Jan 8, 2021

Several other good Defector blogs I read from yesterday:

  • Whose Anger Gets Rewarded? by Kelsey McKinney
    • It took less than 10 minutes to clear Lafayette Square in June. It wasn’t even past curfew, and it was still sunny. It was a Monday. Over the heads of the people in front of me, if I stretched way up on my toes, I could see them: two lines of police force with riot shields.

The Others is fine, a perfectly fine and spooky upscale ghost yarn that makes good use of one of the great movie-stars of her […]

🔗: CD Projekt Red catered to its edgiest fans with Cyberpunk 2077’s marketing | Polygon

Cyberpunk 2077 has mastered parasocial advertising as only the best influencers can, with the game’s Twitter account trading jokes with celebrities like Elon Musk. CD Projekt Red has got everybody talking about this game, though not always for the right reasons.
Jan 4, 2021

🔗: What I Learned From Reading Over A Thousand Letters To Santa | Defector

I wanted to know what kids were asking Santa for during a pandemic, so each day from Dec. 4, the day the first batch of letters hit the website, to Dec. 13, I spent hours engaged in the surreal, intimate, heart-wrenching practice of reading children’s letters to Santa Claus one after another—about a thousand in all. This year, Operation Santa is an explicit look at the disastrous impact of COVID-19 on America’s poor and the utter failure of the government's response.
Jan 4, 2021

🔗: Only Donald Trump Gets To Lie Like This | Defector

You have probably not seen the Staten Island-based bitcoin apostle, conservative activist, and Newsmax TV studio host John Tabacco’s appearances on Joe Piscopo’s morning radio show, but they are exceedingly easy to imagine accurately. Close your eyes or open YouTube and you can see Tabacco sitting next to Piscopo’s co-host Frankie Five Boroughs, wearing a suit and tie and talking about whatever has Staten Island upset at that moment.

I wanted to know what kids were asking Santa for during a pandemic, so each day from Dec. 4, the day the first batch of letters hit the website, to Dec. 13, I spent hours engaged in the surreal, intimate, heart-wrenching practice of reading children’s letters to Santa Claus one after another—about a thousand in all. This year, Operation Santa is an explicit look at the disastrous impact of COVID-19 on America’s poor and the utter failure of the government’s response.

2021/01/04 16:22

Jan 4, 2021

This year, Operation Santa is an explicit look at the disastrous impact of COVID-19 on America’s poor and the utter failure of the government's response.

Jan 4, 2021

🔗: Only Donald Trump Gets To Lie Like This | Defector

You have probably not seen the Staten Island-based bitcoin apostle, conservative activist, and Newsmax TV studio host John Tabacco’s appearances on Joe Piscopo’s morning radio show, but they are exceedingly easy to imagine accurately. Close your eyes or open YouTube and you can see Tabacco sitting next to Piscopo’s co-host Frankie Five Boroughs, wearing a suit and tie and talking about whatever has Staten Island upset at that moment.

2020 Year In Review

Jan 4, 2021

I only have a bit to add to the correct notion here that 2020 is not worth recapping. I was extraordinarily fortunate and lucky over the past year. I got a new job, and no one in my immediate bubble has caught the plague going around. I was able to chronicle how different everything was.

The only thing to add to this notion is a general, simmering rage that has been building since March. From forcing everything to reopen, to brand new kindergarten students having to learn over Zoom calls, to seeing other countries able to hold large gatherings in the fall, to watching helplessly as doses of the miraculous vaccination expire, unused. My trust in basically everyone currently in a position of power is gone, unlikely to be repaired. Little acts along the way help, but I am not sure the rage will ever subside.

I will think about other little acts while I go noodle around some more with TiddlyWiki.

Separation Sunday

Nov 5, 2020

Since college, this has been my go-to listening during crunch time. From the microcontroller final class project to my current job, it has yet to fail me. Just helped me get through another tight schedule.

youtu.be/dYU2yqaHq…

It only seems to work if I listen to the whole thing, but once the piano outro starts in "How A Resurrection Really Feels", my work is done.

I have never met a hoodrat. I have never drank gin from a jam jar, let alone in an emergency room. Never been shaken or stirred in a dirty storefront church. Chicago has never seemed tired to me. Still, the album speaks to me.

Everyone seems to have a go-to for this situation. If for some reason you need one, you cannot go wrong with Separation Sunday.

Post-election-day brain dump

Nov 4, 2020

During the primaries, the mild, establishment candidate muscles out a popular challenger from the left, securing their party nomination. This mild candidate is running against an obviously bad one fielded by the other party, self-evidently unable to do the job.

Aforementioned mild candidate then does not worry about creating an affirmative case for themself, and why would they? Their opponent is obviously bad. Much easier to say "wow, doesn't that guy suck?" than to create plans to help fix the myriad of things that are broken.

This mild candidate does not campaign in battleground states (this time around, because it's responsible and prudent), instead focused on fundraising from large-money donors.

Polling goes heavy in this candidate's favor. There is just no way the obviously bad candidate could pull this out. The obviously bad candidate has a brush with his own hubris in early October, solidifying polling through the election.

Getting surprised on election day would be the definition of insanity, right?

I've made peace with results over the last couple weeks. At least we are nearing that result, one way or another. #mbnov

Sep 4, 2020

time to try Marvel’s Avengers 🎮

August 26

Aug 27, 2020

Yesterday was harrowing for many reasons, and I want to write them all out for posterity.

We woke at 6am to the sound of my father-in-law bailing water out of our basement, which had flooded. Water bubbling up from under our front walk - the well line had broken, so I shut off our water. Spent the next few hours drying it out. Talked to the people that installed the well, who told us he would need an excavating tool which he did not have to get through any tree roots, etc., to fix it.

Brief work phone call to find out our project end date has been moved up 2 months by our client, to October 1. No pressure, but not something you expect to hear very often.

Occasional social media checks show someone shot 3 protesters in Kenosha, killing 2. Horrifying details emerge over the rest of the day, interspersed with hurricane and pandemic news.

Called several neighbors, checked BBB, to get names of excavators. Couldn't get ahold of anyone until mid- to late-afternoon, and no one would be able to come out today.

Took a walk to blow off steam with the wife. Saw a couple small squirrels cross the road ahead of us. When we catch up to that point, we are startled by a snake who, upon further inspection, is eating one of the squirrels. Ominous.

Heard back from insurance company, who will cover the water damage but not the well repair (apparently a standard practice). Understandable but disappointing. Also, they have no contacts to suggest for the repair - more disappointing.

Wildcat strike by the Milwaukee Bucks, followed by the rest of the NBA teams on that days schedule, then WNBA, MLB, and MLS. Baller move, fills me with hope. I hope this pushes things forward in the right direction.

Here's hoping August 27 is better.

Aug 26, 2020

Day 26 of #mbaug: relentless 🐕

Aug 24, 2020

Day 24 of #mbaug: frosty ☃️

Aug 23, 2020

Day 23 of #mbaug: graceful 🐕

The inward (mobile) search

Aug 23, 2020

I’ve had this on my mind for a few years now, and was reminded by this article about how Apple will reject Stadia and xCloud from the App Store. I’m a fan of both of those services so far, but my thoughts are tangential to Apple’s locked down platform. The nit I am picking is with search.

There is an almost throwaway line in Apple’s policy about how all the games would need to be reviewed and available in search. In direct relation to this issue, the policy is dumb and will likely fold, either to antitrust inquiries or backdoor handshake deals (or both). It creates a bad user experience (people who want to use the service on iOS cannot) for the sake of a good user interface.

I can’t fault them for it. In my 10 years using smartphones, I was able to switch to iOS for an entire 6 weeks, around the end of 2015. The only thing that still haunts me as an Android user is Spotlight Search.

It underscores the core design difference between the two systems. There is a single iOS which everyone experieces, but users bring along their individual stuff into the walled garden. On Android, you are generally encourged to create your own unique experience, which is rewarding in itself. However, trying to access personal items is a hassle, as search is almost always pointed outward toward the G-shaped hive mind.

I’ve spent several weeks organizing personal notes, experimenting with new tools. The interoperability and longevity of plaintext notes has proven particular alluring, and quite useful in practice. But if I want to perform a mobile search that includes my personal files as well as relevant emails/todos/etc., I am out of luck. The market leader to end all market leaders of internet search fails to accomplish this, and probably on purpose, because again, all search points outward by design.

Anyways, this has been bugging me for years, and won’t get any better because I just got my next Android phone. On a related note, I look forward to Obsidian coming to mobile.

2020/08/23 04:03

Indiana coronavirus: Why 1,000 new cases a day may not be a red flag

Aug 14, 2020

How Marion County schools hope to reopen safely

Marion County has issued guidance on how to reopen schools safely during the coronavirus pandemic and the new public health order goes into effect on Aug. 6. Here's how it will work.

This headline is malpractice. As best I can tell, the expert quotes point to more testing availability possibly increasing the number, different metrics (7-day positivity) being more useful, and college contact tracing plans (?). Like saying “well the flag is really more of a maroon than a red” 😡

🔗: I Scored Worse Than Donald Trump Did on That Brain Test | The New Republic

Why the president’s claim that he got “all 35” questions right on the Montreal Cognitive Assessment is meaningless.

2020/08/08 04:02

Aug 8, 2020

🔗: The US declared war on TikTok because it can’t handle the truth | Sarah Jeong (The Verge)

The battle over TikTok’s ownership is only one part of a much larger war. The US, China, and Russia have adopted a philosophy of “information-nationalism,” where telling lies about your own country strengthens it, and telling the truth about other countries weakens them. This is an enormous change from the US’s previous internet policy — and likely a bad one.

🔗: The US declared war on TikTok because it can’t handle the truth

The battle over TikTok’s ownership is only one part of a much larger war. The US, China, and Russia have adopted a philosophy of “information-nationalism,” where telling lies about your own country strengthens it, and telling the truth about other countries weakens them. End of a music era

Jun 24, 2020

I was lucky enough to get into Google Music early, by invitation. I have used it ever since, with a 1-month hiatus around 2014 to determine that Rdio was the best streaming service available (lol). In reality, the only option at the time for people with iPod-filling-sized music collections was Google Music. You could probably run a Subsonic server or something, but that stuff was for nerds. This was one of the largest companies in the world, offering a consumer solution for a consumer problem.

This was all before the wide realization of Google’s penchant for killing its offerings that people actually liked. But this one has obviously been much harder - they’ve started trying to kill their original music service over 2 years ago with no luck.

Youtube (in terms of branding) is already a step down. It has its own trouble with extremism, etc. Also, streaming music on Youtube always seemed like an anachronism to me - your medium is wrong, you are using unnecessary bandwidth, also you aren’t cool enough to have amassed your own collection. Can’t beat (ad-supported) free, I guess.

Grandfathering into the early adopter’s rate has saved me roughly $160 so far, over Spotify and others. May not be enough monetarily to justify staying, but it is enough to say I got in before it was cool. And to people who curate music collections, that is worth more lol.

The wrench in all this is I got a 3 month trial to Tidal, and it is going pretty well so far. It apparently can be combined with Plex, which may be getting back to that holy grail of mine + theirs. Will have a decision to make soon.

Jun 22, 2020

🔗: Nancy by Olivia Jaimes for May 25, 2020 | GoComics.com

Hosting multiple TiddlyWikis on Node

Jun 20, 2020

I only recently1 found out about TiddlyWiki, and immediately became enamored with it. After a couple months of playing with individual files, today I made a breakthrough today in hosting TiddlyWiki on my site.

I tried a few ways to initialize with cPanel on my current host, without any luck (I may return to this next, now that I’ve seen it in action. It turned out to be much easier to spin up a DigitalOcean droplet with Node, and follow the instructions in this guide from Josh Sullivan. The only modification I made was to use pm2 instead of forever (as DigitalOcean already had it configured). I found another article on initializing pm2 with Tiddlywiki, and I used the following command in place of forever:

pm2 start –name wikiprocessname /lib/node_modules/tiddlywiki/tiddlywiki.js – nameofwikifolder –listen author=name username=name password=yourpassword “readers=(anon)"

Now, my experimentation with TiddlyWiki involved saving single html files and playing with each individually. I ended up with a few single-topic wikis - one for archiving my old notebooks, one for my video game collection, etc. I may combine at some point, but I thought it would be better for now to host individually. All that needed to happen, at least with the DigitalOcean reverse proxy setup, was to initialize nginx correctly.

sudo nano /etc/nginx/sites-available/DOMAIN2.COM sudo nano /etc/nginx/sites-available/DOMAIN3.COM

Then in each file, make sure the port is unique and the URL matches. Symbol links for each:

sudo ln -s /etc/nginx/sites-available/DOMAIN2.COM /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/ sudo ln -s /etc/nginx/sites-available/DOMAIN3.COM /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/

Rerun certbot if needed for these URLs, then intialize each in pm2:

pm2 start –name wikiprocessname /lib/node_modules/tiddlywiki/tiddlywiki.js – nameofwikifolder –listen port=#### author=name username=name password=yourpassword “readers=(anon)"

You can play with the various arguments for the TiddlyWiki webserver outlined here. I made a couple available to only myself for now by removing “readers=(anon)”. Don’t forget to run pm2 save so your server stays up.

Going to keep playing, but right now my commonplace book is live with barely anything in it. Hope this helps someone get theirs off the ground as well.

  1. Pretty sure I picked up the idea from Chris Aldrich, who wrote his own guide for hosting the single file version of TiddlyWiki.↩

Jun 1, 2020

🔗: The Technium: 68 Bits of Unsolicited Advice

some good rules of thumb here. my favorites:

  • Promptness is a sign of respect.
  • Trust me: there is no "them".
  • Art is in what you leave out.
  • Pros are just amateurs who know how to cover their mistakes.
  • Separate the processes of creation from improving. You can’t write and edit, or sculpt and polish, or make and analyze at the same time. If you do, the editor stops the creator. While you invent, don’t select. While you sketch, don’t inspect. While you write the first draft, don’t reflect. At the start, the creator mind must be unleashed from judgement.

img src=“http://www.wired.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/mst3k3_large.jpg">

Four questions: May 26

May 27, 2020

I've been meaning to do this for a month, and got halfway through a couple drafts, but here are my four questions for the day.

1. What did you do today?

Today I got ahead of some test case writing for our next SW release. I started writing tests for a defect that, as it turns out, cannot be fixed until some COVID-19 related change requests are rolled back out. So, on to other tasks.

On the personal project side, I am working through annotating my old notebooks. My original plan was using Evernote OCR, but their price hike has me looking other places. I tried Notion for this, but now I'm experimenting with TiddlyWiki. It is time consuming, but also a good in-depth review, which is part of the point of keeping a notebook.

Later, I introduced my son to Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker. This was probably a mistake, as he can't quite read all the dialog, and thus gets very frustrated by the man trying to teach him sword techniques. Will probably try to get him into Scribblenauts for the time being - he is getting too good at Smash Bros. and Mario Kart.

2. What did you enjoy?

I relish any chance to get out of the house now, even if it's just a short grocery trip. I use the time in the car by myself to scream sing some of my favorite songs. This time it was Entitlement Crew by The Hold Steady.

I also am figuring out how to spend leisure time, around a house where there is always another project to pick up. The backlog of projects and leisure activities both have never felt bigger, since you are always in their proximity now, and it is good to be able to balance them. I am nearly finished with A Link To The Past, and hope to knock out The Outer Worlds soon.

3. What did you find difficult?

Watching people try to go back to the way things were already. The large Memorial day gatherings. Seeing the data about how other countries have nearly wiped out the threat of the virus, while meanwhile we are "re-"opening before the case numbers have even peaked in most places.

4. What has changed?

Over the last two months, so much. This is difficult to quantify, as we were in the middle of a lot of change already. I started this new job, and have spent a total of 1 day in the office. Our kid has stayed home for most of that time, and is just now beginning to get restless.

And now, since this is my first entry, on to the stretch questions.

5. What are you grateful for?

I am so thankful for our health. We are in an extremely privileged position to be able to isolate ourselves, and I know many are not so lucky.

6. What changes do you want to keep?

At work, our project lead now has data for our clients that we are actually more productive from home, and, among other proposals to them on when to return, proposed staying remote permanently. I would not be opposed to this, although at this point I would love the option to go into the office (or somewhere) occasionally.

7. What are you scared of?

Same as everyone else - dying alone, isolated from those close to me. Woke me up briefly last night, thinking about it.

We are also living with an immuno-compromised person, so becoming a vector for the virus is also a big fear at the moment.

8. What has stayed the same?

Day to day, things have normalized (in contrast to question 4). We have a routine now. Charlie is probably to the point where he misses his alone time during the day.

9. When did you last laugh?

I have not had much trouble laughing, when the moment is right (again, we are very lucky). The hardest I've laughed over the last couple months was watching Popstar. In the last few days, my biggest laugh was seeing this dumb tweet.

I said we can hug again when the coughs are all gone - Welcome to Hell World

May 27, 2020

🔗: I said we can hug again when the coughs are all gone | Welcome to Hell World

May 17, 2020

🔗: The Best Games For The Game Boy Advance | Kotaku

If you played games in the early 2000s, you probably did so on a Game Boy Advance. First introduced in 2001 as a purple, vaguely hexagonal brick, the hardware boost alone over the Game Boy Color’s archaic tech ushered in an era of lush pixelated gameplay. Then came the ultra-stylish Game Boy Advance SP. Complete with flip-phone-like functionality and a light-up screen, one thing was certain: Game Boy Advance was the handheld of the generation. By the end of its impressive run, enough excellent games came out to fill the Library of Alexandria. Here, as decided by the writers and editors of Kotaku, are the cream of the crop.

🔗: The Oral History Of Michael Jordan’s Legendary ‘Flu Game’ | Clickhole

It’s one of those images that stays with you forever: Michael Jordan, the greatest basketball player who ever lived, collapsing helplessly into the arms of Scottie Pippen following Game 5 of the 1997 NBA Finals. Ignoring the limitations of his flu-ravaged body, Jordan mustered a spectacular 38-point performance to elevate his Chicago Bulls over the Utah Jazz, paving the way for his fifth championship in seven years. Now, nearly two decades later, those who were there for the storied game have come together to describe what it was like to be part of history.

Stadia vs. xCloud

Mar 31, 2020

I am lucky enough to be in both the (soft-)launch of Google Stadia and the beta of project xCloud from Microsoft. Some thoughts on the differences between the two:

  • Stadia works a bit like Xbox Live. You pay a monthly fee, and get a couple games added to your library each month. You lose access if you lapse the subscription, but regain them if you renew again. Xbox costs half as much if you pay annually - not sure Stadia offers that yet.
  • xCloud has 2 options at the moment - stream games from their servers (similar to Stadia), or stream your own games from your own console (this requires opt-in for beta testing the OS on your console).
  • While both work best on 5 GHz band wifi, Stadia gives a more general "you're good!" connection status, while xCloud will specifically tell you to get on 5 GHz for the best performance. The difference here is you can keep going on Stadia, and xCloud will generally lag and shutdown the stream to change the connection.
  • Playing a console game on a phone isn't terrible, but is not yet ideal. As it becomes more widespread, I would guess games would adapt their display settings for this, but right now, it's a lot of tiny text menus.

Of course the biggest difference is the platform buy-in (and I suspect this will be the case with Nvidia GeForce Now as well, if they can stop hemorrhaging games). I have nearly 15 years of game saves and purchases and achievements on one of these platforms. One of the best reasons to set that aside would be ubiquity - if I can pick up a game and play on any screen1, it would be hard to beat the convenience.2

Google has that opportunity, if it wants. The next play is for your triple-A game library to follow you wherever you go. They’ve just got to move quickly, before someone else beats them to it.

  1. Unless it is an Apple screen...↩
  2. Not that I can get to to many other screens right now, given we can't leave the house.↩

🔗: Open source, experimental, and tiny tools roundup

new beginnings

Mar 14, 2020

Yesterday was my last day at Delphi Technologies. It was my first real job out of college.

I thoroughly enjoyed my time there. It was challenging and fulfilling, starting in test automation for embedded systems, and ending as a product owner on a cross-functional development team. As with any rewarding endeavor, I constantly went back and forth between “I need to leave this place” and “I’m going to retire here.” Ended up going with the first one, but I got nine years of experience and friendships to show for it.

It was bittersweet. I am simultaneously excited for the future, and sad to leave my coworkers (if any of you find this - Hi! I have a blog). I wish them all the best - they are well equipped for the challenges ahead.

I accepted a job offer to return to software testing - this time on web and consumer-facing applications. That was two weeks ago, and now there is a high possibility that my onboarding Monday will be remote. Pandemics move fast. Still extremely excited, with that twinge of apprehension that comes with speeding toward the unknown.

To new beginnings.

updated now page, post to follow

Mar 14, 2020

updated now page, post to follow

🔗: The Democrats’ Cult of Pragmatism | New Republic

Joe Biden, Hillary Clinton, and other moderates claim they Get Things Done—but not because they actually do get things done.

img src=“https://images.newrepublic.com/dc1df9110a4493b7358f538c37c4b0593b15204e.jpeg?w=1000" />

Pappy

Mar 8, 2020

Our kid is in imaginary friend stage. The thing is, his imaginary friend is named Pappy. Pappy is his other dad.

Pappy is constantly one-upping us, his actual parents. Pappy lives on a lake with his pet shark, Hammy. Pappy’s house is a little bigger than our new house, but “not as big as a building. It’s like 68 meters tall.”

Very matter-of-fact, as I was walking out of his room after saying goodnight, he called me back to tell me something. “I need you to go tell Mommy this: Pappy robbed a bank and then he had to go to jail. Ok, goodnight Dad.”

Anyway, watch this space for further Pappy updates, to find out how he has humiliated us this time.

My Todoist Year in Review 2019!

Jan 13, 2020

🔗: My Todoist Year in Review 2019!

Todoist helped me keep track of everything I accomplished in 2019!

another year of only using the tool for part of the year. really need a write up on my notebook habit

Year in Review 2019 and Decade In Review 2010s

Dec 31, 2019

In late December 2009 I was playing Elder Scrolls: Oblivion in my college apartment, and got into a spat with my girlfriend, who was disappointed that I was spending money on games and not thinking about the future. That capped off the previous decade.

From there, I got a ring proposed in March, graduated college the next December, got a job and got married in 2011, got Charlie in 2012, bought a house in 2013, had a kid in 2015, moved and helped Jessie start law school also in 2015. Most of the rest can be pieced together from previous years-in-review. Basically, we have all come a long way, and it has been a great decade.

2019 has been a hectic and fulfilling year, both professionally and personally. At work we are nearing production release for our first Agile-led project. At home, we are adjusting to Jessie graduating, passing the bar, and becoming a lawyer. We are capping it off by buying a house, but that is going to be a 2020 story.

Best tweets of 2019, sort of by date

(I’ll probably do a decade tweet retrospective later)

  • [](https://twitter.com/dril/status/1207068094553673728?s=20)

    i am pleased to announce, that i have Normalized beer

    [me telling my story how I survived a plane crash and lived on a deserted island for a year] it was crazy
    [friend who once got a text from me where I accidentally called the grinch the grink] was the grink there?

    — brent (@murrman5) October 1, 2019

 Music and Media

There were only 2 songs worth keeping on repeat for most of the year. They are:

Denver Haircut by the Hold Steady

Sunflower by Vampire Weekend

I did not see many movies, but these were the best ones that I did see. Here’s my decade list - still a work in progress

Best TV of the year, in my opinion, was The Good Place, Game of Thrones final season, The Witcher, and Good Omens.

Resolutions

My goals and resolutions for the new year will be close to the same as last year. I need to connect with my community, and I need to stick with my good habits. Here is a sampling of those - I made good on getting thrifty on lunch, but not quite on the notebooking habit. I dropped off on drinking water instead of coffee/soda. I also started reading a lot more when I figured out the login to my library’s ebook lending program.

Here’s to another one

Will be enjoying a coffee porter from a local brewery and going to bed early. Midnight is for suckers.

Deadspin Forever

Nov 4, 2019

One of the first RSS feeds I added to Google Reader (RIP) was Deadspin (also RIP). It was always a bright spot in the day, opening the Funbag or Dadspin or the latest goofy/dumb/weird sports blog.1

I will miss Deadspin. It’s voice was funny, irreverent, and genuine, and it was home to several fantastic writers. Others will eulogize the site better, but I will say I started my blog around the time I started reading Deadspin regularly.

Here are my favorites, in no particular order. Read them with several ad blockers on, if you don’t want your RAM to melt.

  • Manti Te’o’s Dead Girlfriend, The Most Heartbreaking And Inspirational Story Of The College Football Season, Is A Hoax - Tim Burke and Jack Dickey (which lead into…)
  • An Oral History Of Our “Go Fuck Yourself” Tweet To Donald Trump
  • Pain Is A Gift, And Other Notes From A Terrified Father During A Seven-Week-Premature Birth - Drew Magary
  • I Was an NFL Player Until I Was Fired By Two Cowards And A Bigot - Chris Kluwe
  • The Future Of The Culture Wars Is Here, And It’s Gamergate - Kyle Wagner
  • America Is Not For Black People - Greg Howard
  • The Night The Lights Went Out - Drew Magary
  • The Xbox One Is Garbage and The Future Is Bullshit - Albert Burneko
  • How To Watch Football On Television, According to 1964 - Jeb Lund
  • Donald Trump Is A Frightened Coward And I Bet $100,000 He Won’t Fight Me - Daniel Roberts
  • The Making Of “Homer At The Bat,” The Episode That Conquered Prime Time 20 Years Ago Tonight - Erik Malinowski
  • An Oral History Of Oddibe McDowell’s Water Bill
  • A Night Out with Linda Cohn - AJ Daulerio
  • Visionary Brain Genius Elon Musk Has Invented The World’s Worst And Most Expensive Subway - Albert Burneko
  • This Is How Things Work Now At G/O Media - Laura Wagner
  • The Adults in the Room - Megan Greenwell

And then, of course, the David J Roth Trump pieces, tagged The Big Wet President.

  • Toward A Working Theory Of What The Fuck Donald Trump Is Even Talking About
  • This Is All Donald Trump Has Left
  • You Can’t Get There From Here
  • Donald Trump Wants This More Than Anything
  • Donald Trump Is Not Going to Let This Hurricane Thing Go
  • This Guy Truly Has No Idea What He’s Talking About
  1. Note the order - it was more engaging when they did not stick to sports.↩

🔗: Donald Trump: We Love Bill Belichick, Don’t We, And Also Curing AIDS? | Deadspin

There are two versions of President Donald Trump that appear in public. They both inhabit the same body—the same Youppi-shaped torso pitched forward at the same implausible angles, same ghost-pale eyelids fluttering alarmingly, same resplendent candyfloss Kangol of hair stuck on top of it like a weird hat—but don’t really seem to be the same person. Both are president, and both seem somehow to have just been informed of that fact. Only one seems to be enjoying it. That one is not the Official Trump that sniffs and mutters and struggles with prompters and prepared text, and who only barely makes it through even the most rote ceremonial duties. Most of the time, though, and whenever Trump has to do something he finds boring or lame for an audience that isn’t allowed to hoot or chant, that version is the one America gets.
Oct 13, 2019

Oct 13, 2019

🔗: This Guy Truly Has No Idea What He’s Talking About | The Concourse

It is a problem for President Donald Trump that it’s often impossible to tell what the hell he’s talking about. This is not one of those signature Trump defects that can readily be spun into a secret strength or as a subtle bit of advanced dealcraft that only experts and initiates can appreciate. His mind is a television that changes channels every three seconds and where every channel has an infomercial on it; it cycles day and night without ever quite cohering into a signal. There is plenty of noise, though, and because Trump so utterly lacks discernment he is constantly interrupting himself with some new bit or blurt. As a result, his average sentence is a parade of wild upstage moves in which whatever thought he’s had most recently is forever blundering into and past the one he had just begun to express—imagine one of those halftime shows at a NBA game in which people throw down wild dunks after leaping off trampolines except there’s a new guy jumping on the trampoline every second and there are frequent midair collisions. Trump also only knows about a hundred words, about a third of which refer to volume or size.
Oct 13, 2019

Sometimes you come across a crime story that breaks your heart, but also leaves you a little bit impressed. Such is the case with the Great Apple Theft of LaPorte County, in which bandits somehow managed to remove 50,000 apples from Williams Orchards without anyone noticing.

🔗: I Broke The Official Jeremy Renner App By Posting The Word “Porno” On It | Stefan Heck

The Butterfly Effect is the idea that a solitary flap of a butterfly’s wings will eventually result in a hurricane halfway across the globe. In the interests of moving forward as a society, and because I don’t think I’ve seen a butterfly in, like, four years, I believe it is time to retire this term and go with something a bit different: the porno effect. It’s fairly self-explanatory, I think, but in case you’re still not following, here’s where I got the idea: merely by posting the word “porno” on the official Jeremy Renner app, I single-handedly obliterated, uh... the official Jeremy Renner app.

🔗: Journaling with rwtxt | jlelse.blog

For about a month now, I do journaling again. Every evening before I go to bed, I try to write down everything that comes to my mind. I usually write what I have done that day, what my emotions where and other things that I thought about during the day. It has a very positive effect to do that. Aug 24, 2019

Thursday was a massive night #thscs @theholdsteady

The Hold Steady at Thalia Hall, 24 Aug 2019

Aug 23, 2019

This was our third Hold Steady show. First one was the Pitchfork Music Festival in 2008, and second was in Indianapolis in 2014.

The Hold Steady has been my go-to since early college, and it has aged much better than other favorites from that time. I maintain that had I not been listening to their first 3 albums on continuous loop for the last 72 hours before finals, I would not have completed my microcontrollers class project and would have failed out of college. Same went the next semester with compilers class. Saved by Barfruit Blues and A Multitude of Casualties.

My only note was that I was looking forward to hearing "Chicago Seemed Tired Last Night", and did not, maybe because it was their first of 3 nights in Chicago and they hadn't been in Chicago last night. I did enjoy their cover of the opening band's song "Fresh Pope."

(I have published this far, far after the fact because I am a busy person, but this needed to be logged at the correct time for posterity.)

🔗: Look At This Weird Thing Donald Trump Just Belched Up | David J Roth (The Concourse)

In March, a young whale beached itself in Davao City, in the Philippines. When scientists from the local museum—it is, delightfully, called D’Bone Collector Natural History Museum—did a necropsy on the whale after its death, they discovered that it had starved to death because its stomach contained an astonishing 88 pounds of plastic trash. Food that might have given the whale actual nourishment simply could not fit around the sea garbage that the poor creature had consumed during its brief life, which National Geographic described as “two dense basketballs of trash,” each of which was hard as a baseball. “By the time we hit 16 rice sacks,” the museum’s curator Darrell Blatchley told National Geographic, “on top of the plastic bags, and the snack bags, and big tangles of nylon ropes, you’re like—seriously?”

keys to being a good editor
- jump in the writer’s google doc and rapidly highlight arbitrary pieces of text while they’re writing
- go to the top of the doc while they’re trying to type and just go to town on backspace/enter
- comment “?” on every 35th word no matter what it is

🔗: The Hold Steady Announce New Album ‘Thrashing Thru The Passion’: Hear ‘Denver Haircut’ | Stereogum

Five years ago, the Hold Steady released Teeth Dreams, their last album. That was the last time they functioned like a regular band. Since then, the great word-spewing Brooklyn rockers have switched things up. Where they once toured relentlessly, they now settle into a single city for a quick residency, playing a bunch of shows in one location. And where they once cranked out classic albums, they've been taking things easier, releasing a track or two at a time on Bandcamp. The Hold Steady started that process in 2017, when they dropped "Entitlement Crew" and "A Snake In The Shower." And they've done it a bunch more times since then; just a few months ago, they did it with "The Last Time That She Talked To Me." That part-timer schedule has allowed them to keep going, and it's let frontman Craig Finn keep making solo albums like this year's I Need A New War. But now, finally, we're getting another new Hold Steady album.

I’m so excited 🎵🎸

Instead, Ryan Cline went off, and Purdue won in overtime, 99-94.

via BoffoSocko

2018 Year-in-reflection

Jan 5, 2019

(and 2017 as well)

What a year(s) it has been. Even if I had written a year in review post for 2017, 2018 still felt like it was five and a half years. But, like 2017, I do not feel like writing one of these posts this year. Maybe it is because it is not as fun as it used to be. Maybe it is because all the things I would put here are already posted, categorized neatly without the need for an EOY summary.

The major theme for me of the past 1-2 years is that I feel like I could not keep up. Everything moved fast, and seemed to constantly accelerate. Professional responsibilities changed, which was exciting and harrowing. Our toddler is a big kid, to the point where he wants to do everything but can’t just yet. The world at large seems to hurdle between inspiration and death spiral, practically minute to minute.

So I’m going to use some of the scrum training we got this year for a full-blown retrospective.1

what went well

I enjoyed sharing my interests with our son. He is old enough to follow and play Telltale Lego games, and enjoys Lego Batman, the Incredibles, and playing as Cappy in Super Mario Odyssey. There was also at least one occasion where he got multiple KO’s in Smash.

We were able to sell our house after failing to do so 3 years ago. It was a great starter house, but it was on the verge of becoming a burden, and now it is someone else’s problem.

I am fairly sure I have not logged in to Facebook in 8-10 months. My wife finally got around to deleting her account - it is probably time for me to do the same.

what didn’t go well

I am consistently depressed by the state of America writ large, and unsure of how to improve it, which feeds the depression because I then feel complicit in the problem. This goes back to recognizing privilege.

what to improve

On a personal level, I need to address my more materialistic urges. I have plenty, and am due for a major konmari.

I spend a lot of free time consuming things, and need to find a project where I can make something instead.

I also need to keep up with the journal habit. In 2017 I filled 9 or 10 pocket notebooks, but only did 3 or 4 in 2018. I’ve picked it back up for this first week of 2019, and I already have a much clearer head.

On a larger scale, I need to figure out how to engage with my community. It’s hard to find the time and energy and cause, but I still need to get out of my shell and help once in a while.

for now…

I will go drink a beer with a picture of a fish on it, and do some dad things.

This is the most I’ve written in a long time - need to get back in this habit too.

  1. For media picks, here is my year in movies. Best games were Breath of the Wild and Smash Bros Ultimate. I am still listening to Masseduction and Everything Now - not sure there was any new music in 2018.

    ↩

IndieWeb Tools

Jan 4, 2019

I need to start keeping a list of these, since it feels like every time I come back to the blog, there is something else to try.

  • IndieWeb Wordpress plugin - encompasses several, including Webmention, Post Kinds, Syndication Links, and Micropub
  • Functionality plugin, to add date/time to posts that do not have a title (titles are frowned upon for micro.blog syndication).
  • Indiebookclub, an IndieWeb friendly version of Goodreads
  • Aperture plugin, to enable Microsub support for aperture.p3k.io
  • Together, a Microsub reader
  • Indigineous, a Microsub reader for mobile
